# Introduction

Root-derived carbon is a key input to soil organic matter (SOM) in both managed and natural ecosystems, yet the role of roots’ chemical composition in determining SOM persistence remains uncertain. Suberin—a hydrophobic, carbon-rich biopolymer found in root cell walls—has been hypothesized to enhance long-term soil carbon storage, but its contribution is debated in light of emerging OM-stability paradigms that emphasize microbial and mineral interactions over intrinsic biochemical recalcitrance. This study investigates how varying suberin content influences mineralization rates and chemical transformations of root-derived organic matter in soil. Using 13C-labeled roots spanning a natural suberin gradient, we tracked decomposition in both intact pots and litterbag microcosms over 30–40 weeks.
